results.title: Dance in education
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: A program that aims to unify folk dance activities throughout the schools of Victoria by highlighting a series of preparatory exercises, dances by primary school children and more sophisticated dances by ethnic groups.

results.title: More 'new' handwriting
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, Diane O'Connor and Materials Production, Curriculum Branch, Ed Dept of Vic
results.brief_description: This is a sequel to”The New handwriting” which is part of a compilation tape entitled “Learning handwriting” It provides practical advice on such issues as the use of speed loops, alternative letter shapings and embellished handwriting. Also looks at teacher reactions to the change in style.

results.title: Beating the clock - at sport: the limits of human performance
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, Steve Skok and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: One of a series of programmes produced in conjunction with the Youth ANZAAS Science Festival. While looking at the differences in human performances at Olympic Games, the question is raised as to how one person can do so much better than another and why performance times have improved so much
results.title_for_label: Beating the clock - at sport: the limits of human performance

results.title: Winter
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, David Ferris, TV Ed Productions and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: This program hosted by Trevor Lunn and Kevin Koala invite guests to explain just what is Winter and how does the season affect us and the plants and animals around us. These guests come from the Melbourne Museum Education Service, Royal Melbourne Zoo Education Service and the Victorian Schools Nursery.

results.title: Victorian education history. - No. 1.
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description:
Three programs which show different periods of school life in Victoria. “A Day at Ascot-Vale School no. 2608” is a silent film showing some of the daily activities at a primary school in the twenties. The second film is silent and untitled, but shows life at a primary school in the 40’s or 50’s. The third film is similarly untitled but is in colour and with sound. It shows different aspects of teaching in Victoria in the 50’s, with a substantial section on teacher training and country schools. “Each one is different” introduces the concept of child-centred education in Victorian schools.

NFSA description:

1. Portrays the outdoor life at a school in Melbourne in the 1920’s. Shows school dress, assembly, physical training organised dancing and games, Junior Red Cross activities, mothers club and school committee. #2. Shows the then new facilities for infant children at South West Brunswick Primary School. #3. A teacher recruitment film for the Victorian Education Dept. Describes the training of primary teachers. #4. Aims to show how individual differences in children can be catered for in a primary school physical education program. Describes the basic skills of gymnastics and the techniques of supporting, transferring and managing the body weight through different activities.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development

results.title: Matter of life and death
results.creator_credit: Trevor Lunn and Healthsharing Women. Publishing and Production Group
results.brief_description: Alan Grossbard, an education officer with the State Electricity Commission in Victoria, talks about some of the features of electricity and the potentially dangerous results if it is misused.

results.title: Carnivore capers
results.creator_credit: Mark Laughlin, Tony Paice and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: This program set in the Royal Melbourne Zoo looks at three types of carnivores - lions, cape hunting dogs and seals, and follows the keeper through a typical day.
